items.summary: 1 white plastic item reported. The incidence of plastics reported was 0,3% (n=296)

items.summary: 5 plastic items reported, where 40% was white, 40% was hyaline and 20% black. The incidence of plastics reported was 6,8% (n=73)
items.reference: Romeo, T., Peda, C., Fossi, M.C., Andaloro, F. & Battaglia, P. (2016). First record of plastic debris in the stomach of Mediterranean lanternfishes. Acta Adriatica, 57(1), 115-124

items.summary: 3 plastic items reported, where 33% were hyaline, 33% grey and 34% black. The incidence of plastics reported was 4,2% (n=71)

items.summary: 5 plastic fragments reported, where 40% was hyaline, 40% yellow and 20% brown. The incidence of plastics reported was 6,1% (n=82)
items.reference: Romeo, T., Peda, C., Fossi, M.C., Andaloro, F. & Battaglia, P. (2016). First record of plastic debris in the stomach of Mediterranean lanternfishes. Acta Adriatica, 57(1), 115-124

items.summary: Floatsam (marine debris) was found in 21 fish  wchih constitute 7,34% of the fish analysed. Three contained pieces of paper, tinfoil and cigarette ends
items.reference: Dorman, J.A. (1988). Diet of the garfish, Belone belone (L.), from Courtmacsherry Bay, Ireland. Journal of Fish Biology, 33, 333-346

items.summary: Study carried out with fish from the Tagus estuary. Plastic and synthetic fibers such nylon was included within the Detritus cathegory with sand and vegetation, and occurred in 30.34%
items.reference: Assis, C.A., Almeida, P.R., Moreira, F., Costa, J.L. & Costa, M.J. (1992). Diet of the twaite shad Alosa fallax (Lacépède)(Clupeidae) in the River Tagus estuary, Portugal. Journal of Fish Biology, 41(6), 1049-1050

items.summary: An empty plastic carrier bag was recovered from the stomach of a 153 cm male, and a plastic refuse sack containing potato peel, orange peel and onion peel, was recovered from the stomach of a 179 cm female
items.reference: Henderson, A.C., Flannery, K. & Dunne, J. (2001). Observations on the biology and ecology of the blue shark in the North‐east Atlantic. Journal of Fish Biology, 58(5), 1347-1358

items.summary: Greenland, Iceland, USA, Canary Islands: Two sharks (5.41FO%) contained fishig gear and a plastic bag.

(2007). Distribution, reproduction and feeding of the Greenland shark Somniosus (Somniosus) microcephalus, with notes on two other sleeper sharks, Somniosus (Somniosus) pacificus and Somniosus (Somniosus) antarcticus. Journal of Fish Biology, 70(2), 374–390

items.summary: "For S.brasiliensis, the highest ingestion of nylon fragments was observed in adults and juveniles during the rainy season in the upper estuary."

items.summary: A knife of brass of about 7cm length was found imbedded in the flesh

items.summary: Garbage (recorded as detritus) was foun in 10 stomachs out of 252. The detritus "included fragments of plastic and rubber sheeting, cardboard, string, nylon thread, and tin foil".
items.reference: Waller, G.N.H. & Baranes, A. (1994). Food of Iago omanensis, a deep water shark from the northern Red Sea. Journal of Fish Biology, 45, 37-45

items.Area: National Park of Doñana, Andalucía, Spain
items.summary: A total 293 scats were analysed and Litter was found in 21 (7,2%), 9 (7%, n=129) scats where collected at the uplands and 12 (7,2%, n=164) at the Dehesa ecosystem.
items.reference: Fedriani, J.M. 1996. Dieta anual del zorro, Vulpes vulpes, en dos hábitats del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 23(2), 143-152

items.Area: National Park of Doñana, Andalucía, Spain
items.summary: A total of 65 stomachs investigated fron 1974 to 1981 and anthropogenic rubbish (some identify as cardboard) was found in afrequency of 1,37% in Autumn, 4,35% in Spring, and 7,5% in Summer. No anthropogenic rubbish was found in faecal analysis (n=120) collected between 1979 and 1981
items.reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

items.Area: National Park of Doñana, Andalucía, Spain
items.summary: A total of 74 stomachs were analized from 1976 to 1981. Two stomachs (6,67%) collected in Autumn contained plastic bags. Nine stomachs (28,13%) collected in winter contained plastic bags, while one stomach contained cigarrette bugs. Another stomach collected in Spring (10%F) contained plastic bags, but also a piece of a rope and socks were found. All stomachs collected in Summer (n=2) contained plastic bags. A total of 120 faecal samples were collected from October 1979 and July 1981 and anthropogenic items were found.
items.reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

items.Area: National Park of Doñana, Andalucía, Spain
items.summary: A total of 54 stomachs were analysed from 1976 to 1981. Only a piece of rope was found in one stomach (12,77%) collected in Summer. A total of 120 faecal samples were collected from October 1979 and July 1981 and anthropogenic items were found.
items.reference: Venero, J.L. (1984). Dieta de los grandes fitófagos del Parque Nacional de Doñana. Doñana Acta Vertebrata, 11(3), 130

items.summary: Garbage appeared in stomachs from 1965 with a 42,8%F and 5.3%Volume, and in 1966 with a 47,8%F and 11.8%volume. In general, Grabage was the forth most important item in terms of volume and eight in terms of frequency.
items.reference: Henry, V.G. & Conley, R.H. (1972). Fall Foods of European Wild Hogs in the Southern Appalachians. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 36(3), 854

items.summary: Garbage/Rubbish was found in 11 scats (48%F) and consitituted the 23.3% of the drymatter (n=25). Garbage included plastics, paper and ropes.
items.reference: Martin-Azcarte, Yanes, M. & Suarez, F. 1994. Acerca de la dieta primaveral de perros asilvestrados (Canis familiaris) en una localidad del sureste ibérico. Doñana Acta Vertebrata, 21(2), 193-198

items.Area: Parque Natural del Cabo de Gata-Níjar (36Q 50' N, 2Q 25' W, O-50 m.s.n.m
items.summary: Garbage/Rubbish was found in 6 scats (8.7%F), which constitutes the 4.3% of the drymatter (n=69). Garbage included plastics, paper and ropes.
items.reference: Martin-Azcarte, Yanes, M. & Suarez, F. 1994. Acerca de la dieta primaveral de perros asilvestrados (Canis familiaris) en una localidad del sureste ibérico. Doñana Acta Vertebrata, 21(2), 193-198

items.summary: A total of 166 stomachs were analysed (half assumed Feral dogs), where 7 stomachs (4,2%F, 1,2%V) cointained garbage and newspaper fragments.
items.reference: Coman, B.J. 1972. Helminth parasites of the Dingo and Feral dog in Victoria with some notes on the diet of the host. Australian Veterinary Journal, 48, 456-461

items.Sampling information: From February to June 2000 & from April to June 2001

items.summary: 40 lead bullets with necrotic tissue in the stomach

items.summary: From the total of 76 stomachs and 12 rectal samples, 6 (8%FO) and 2 (15,4%FO) samples from two different areas contained carrion and rubbish. A total of 5 items (2,4%N) and 1 item (0,9%N) were recorded respectively

items.summary: Pieces of plastic or rubber

items.summary: The study is focussed at the Big Rivers and Wetlands Field Station in Jackson (Missouri). It is reported that few fish had consumed larger inorganic items, such as rocks, silicone caulking, and rubber
